children.title: General guidelines for decision-making and behaviour
Help managers make consistent decisions
Provide a framework for action
Not as rigid as scientific principles
Allow flexibility in application
Can be adapted to different situations
Deal with human behaviour, require creative application
Managers must interpret and apply principles based on people involved
No one-size-fits-all solution
Techniques: Step-by-step methods to achieve goals
Examples: Budgeting, time management, quality control
Principles: Guidelines for decision-making while using techniques
Examples: Unity of command, division of work
Values: Moral standards; principles are technical, values are ethical/social
Examples: Honesty, integrity, fairness
Universal Applicability
Apply to all organizations, but extent varies
Principles are relevant in business, government, NGOs, etc.
Examples: Government office, limited company, etc.
Unity of command applies in both a government office and a private company
General Guidelines
Not straitjacket solutions; help in complex situations
Managers can use discretion within the guidelines
Example: Conflict between departments
Principle of coordination helps resolve disputes
Formed by Practice and Experimentation
Based on experience and research
Principles are tested and refined over time
Example: Discipline, fatigue study
Taylor's fatigue study led to the principle of rest breaks
Flexible
Can be modified as per situation
Managers adapt principles to fit organizational needs
Example: Centralisation vs Decentralisation
Degree of centralisation depends on size and nature of business
Mainly Behavioural
Focus on influencing human behaviour
Principles aim to motivate and guide employees
Example: Factory layout, orderliness
Orderliness principle improves workflow and morale
Cause and Effect Relationship
Help predict outcomes, though not perfectly
Following principles increases chances of success
Example: Emergencies vs participative decision-making
In emergencies, quick decisions override participative approach
Contingent
Application depends on the situation
Managers must judge when and how to apply each principle
Example: Fair remuneration depends on many factors
Remuneration varies by industry, skill, and market conditions
Provide useful insights into real situations
Principles help managers analyze and solve problems
Increase managerial efficiency
Standardized practices save time and effort
Ensure optimum use of resources and effective administration
Principles guide allocation and utilization of resources
Facilitate scientific decision-making
Decisions are based on facts and analysis, not guesswork
Help managers adapt to changing environments
Principles are flexible and can be updated as needed
Encourage fulfilment of social responsibility
Principles promote ethical and responsible behavior
Form the basis for management training, education, and research
Principles are taught in business schools and used in research

Lijjat Papad empowers women and supports communities

Division of Work
Specialization increases output by making employees more efficient.
Example: Assembly line in car manufacturing.
Authority and Responsibility
Managers must have authority to give orders, with equal responsibility.
Example: Supervisor can assign tasks and is accountable for results.
Discipline
Employees must obey and respect rules.
Example: Punctuality and adherence to company policies.
Unity of Command
Each employee should receive orders from only one superior.
Example: Avoids confusion and conflict.
Unity of Direction
One head and one plan for a group of activities with the same objective.
Example: All marketing activities under one manager.
Subordination of Individual Interest to General Interest
Interest of the organization comes before individual interests.
Remuneration
Workers must be paid fairly for their services.
Example: Competitive salaries and incentives.
Centralization and Decentralization
Balance between decision-making at top and lower levels.
Example: Decentralized sales teams, centralized finance.
Scalar Chain
Line of authority from top to bottom.
Example: CEO → Manager → Supervisor → Worker.
Order
People and materials should be in the right place at the right time.
Example: Organized workspace.
Equity
Managers should be kind and fair to subordinates.
Example: No discrimination in promotions.
Stability of Tenure
Long-term employment is important for efficiency.
Example: Low staff turnover.
Initiative
Employees should be encouraged to take initiative.
Example: Suggestion schemes.
Esprit de Corps
Promote team spirit to build harmony and unity.
Example: Team-building activities.

nodes.title: Taylor's Principles and Techniques of Scientific Management

children.title: Principles
Science, not Rule of Thumb
Decisions based on scientific study, not tradition.
Example: Time and motion studies.
Harmony, not Discord
Managers and workers should cooperate.
Example: Profit-sharing plans.
Cooperation, not Individualism
Teamwork is essential.
Example: Group incentives.
Development of each person to their greatest efficiency and prosperity
Training and development maximize potential.
Example: On-the-job training.
Techniques
Functional Foremanship
Eight specialists supervise different aspects of work.
Example: Separate foremen for planning and production.
Standardisation and Simplification of Work
Uniform methods and tools.
Example: Standardized parts in manufacturing.
Method Study, Motion Study, Time Study, Fatigue Study
Analyze and optimize work methods.
Example: Reducing unnecessary movements.
Differential Piece Wage System
Higher pay for higher output.
Example: Bonus for exceeding targets.
